subject: linear_algebra
title: Elementary Row Operations
contentHtml:
Elementary row operations are a fundamental concept in linear algebra, allowing us to manipulate systems of linear equations.

These operations preserve row equivalence and can be used to solve systems of linear equations.
name: Row Addition
variants: [ {"latex": "\[R_i \leftarrow kR_i\] (Row scaling)", "description": "Multiply a row by a non-zero scalar"}, {"latex": "\[R_i \leftrightarrow R_j\] (Row interchange)", "description": "Swap two rows"} ] },
problemHtml:
Consider the system of linear equations:

  • \(2x + y = 3\)
  • \(x - 2y = -1\)
",
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Add twice the first row to the second", "mathHtml": "\[R_2 \leftarrow R_2 + 2R_1\]", "explanation": "This eliminates the x term in the second equation"}, {"stepNumber": 2, "description": "Scale the new second row by -1/3", "mathHtml": "\[R_2 \leftarrow -\frac{1}{3} R_2\]", "explanation": "This makes the coefficient of y equal to 1"} ],
intuition: Elementary row operations allow us to transform a system of linear equations into an equivalent one, making it easier to solve or analyze.
